href="/2025/05/28/opinion/trump-danger-normalization-shock.html">1832</a></span></div></span></li></ul></div></div></div></div><div class="css-p6m5rf"><div class="byline-container css-t91cuf epjyd6m2"><div class="css-1w5zm64 ey68jwv0" aria-hidden="true"><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/m-gessen" class="css-uwwqev"><img alt="M. Gessen" title="M. Gessen" src="https://static01.nyt.com/images/2024/07/19/opinion/masha-gessen-circle/masha-gessen-circle-thumbLarge.png" class="css-owy2rv ey68jwv2"/></a></div><div class="css-ehpuw4 epjyd6m1"><p class="css-1tx0lhj e1jsehar1"><span class="byline-prefix">By </span><a href="https://www.nytimes.com/by/m-gessen" class="last-byline css-ojhyzr e1jsehar0" itemProp="name">M. Gessen</a></p><div class="css-1gqes1i epjyd6m0"><div id="enhanced-byline" class="css-8atqhb"><p class="css-1npznau e1wtpvyy0">Opinion Columnist</p></div></div></div></div></div></header><section name="articleBody" class="meteredContent css-1r7ky0e"><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-0"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">In a show that recently opened at the LaMaMa Experimental Theater Club in the East Village, a group of actors led by a young, ambitious, charmingly naïve director are almost finished rehearsing Chekhov’s “The Seagull” at the famed Moscow Art Theater when Russia invades Ukraine. Thanks to social media, they can hear the sirens and see the bombs falling on Kharkiv and Kyiv.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">We witness the shock and disbelief, the feeling of utter impossibility of staying in one’s country, one’s city, one’s skin that so many people in Moscow experienced in the days after the full-scale invasion. They cry. They shout at one another. One of them frantically packs a suitcase.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">And then the show goes on.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">This isn’t a theater review, and I’m not here to tell you why you should go see the play, “Seagull: True Story.” I have too many social connections to Alexander Molochnikov, the exiled Russian director, and anyway, the current run is sold out. I’m interested in something else: that moment when the shock fades and the (figurative) show goes on.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">I think we are entering that moment in the United States.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Living in and reporting on Russia when Vladimir Putin took and consolidated power, I was shocked many times. I couldn’t sleep in September 2004, after tanks shelled a school in which terrorists were holding hundreds of children hostage, and I was shocked when Putin used this terrorist attack as a pretext to eliminate elected governorships.</p></div><aside class="css-ew4tgv" aria-label="companion column"></aside></div><div data-testid="Dropzone-1"></div><div class="css-s99gbd StoryBodyCompanionColumn" data-testid="companionColumn-1"><div class="css-53u6y8"><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">I was shaken when Russia invaded Georgia in 2008. My world changed when three very young women were sentenced to jail time for a protest performance in a church in 2012, the first time Russian citizens were imprisoned for peaceful action. I couldn’t breathe when Russia annexed Crimea in 2014. And when the opposition leader Aleksei Navalny was poisoned in 2020, arrested in 2021 and almost certainly killed in prison in 2024. And when Russia again invaded Ukraine in 2022.</p><p class="css-at9mc1 evys1bk0">Along the way there were many smaller, yet also catastrophic, milestones: the state takeovers of universities and media outlets, the series of legislative steps that outlawed L.G.B.T.Q. people, the branding of many journalists and activists as “foreign agents.” The state of shock would last a day or a week or a month, but time went on and the shocking event became a fact of our lives.</p><div class="css-kbghgg"><div class="css-121kum4"><div class="css-171quhb"></div><div class="css-asuuk5"><noscript><div class="css-7axq9l" data-testid="optimistic-truncator-noscript"><svg width="24" height="24" viewBox="0 0 24 24" aria-hidden="true" class="css-1b5b8u1"><path fill="currentColor" fill-rule="evenodd" d="M2.5 12a9.5 9.5 0 1 1 19 0 9.5 9.5 0 0 1-19 0Zm8.5 1.75v-7.5h2v7.5h-2Zm0 2v2h2v-2h-2Z" clip-rule="evenodd"></path></svg><div data-testid="optimistic-truncator-noscript-message" class="css-6yo1no"><p class="css-3kpklk">We are having trouble retrieving the article content.</p><p class="css-3kpklk">Please enable JavaScript in your browser settings.</p></div></div></noscript><div class="css-1dv1kvn" id="optimistic-truncator-a11y" tabindex="-1"><hr/><p>Thank you for your patience while we verify access.
